title: Thames A.F.C.
text:
Thames Association Football Club were an English <a href="association%20football">football</a> club from <a href="Custom%20House%2C%20Newham">Custom House</a>, east London (at the time part of <a href="Essex">Essex</a>), who briefly played in <a href="the%20Football%20League">the Football League</a> between <a href="1930%20in%20association%20football">1930</a> and <a href="1932%20in%20association%20football">1932</a>.
Name.
Unlike other AFCs such as <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland A.F.C.</a>, the word Association was initially presented as part of the club name – i.e. Thames Association or Thames Association FC. The "Association" was abbreviated upon joining the Football League, giving the team the more regular name of Thames AFC.
History.
They were founded in <a href="1928%20in%20association%20football">1928</a>, in a similar manner to <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a>, <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>, <a href="New%20Brighton%20Tower%20F.C.">New Brighton Tower</a> and nearby <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a>: to play on a ground which had no football club in residence. In Thames' case, they were formed by a group of businessmen who had built the <a href="West%20Ham%20Stadium">West Ham Stadium</a>, with a capacity of 120,000, in the <a href="Custom%20House%2C%20Newham">Custom House</a> area of Essex (now part of the <a href="London%20Borough%20of%20Newham">London Borough of Newham</a> in <a href="Greater%20London">Greater London</a>); the stadium was primarily used for <a href="greyhound">greyhound</a> and <a href="motorcycle%20speedway">speedway</a> racing which took place during the week, leaving Saturdays free. The directors of the stadium decided to form a professional football club to play on Saturdays, to bring in additional revenue to the stadium.
The club began playing in the <a href="Southern%20Football%20League">Southern League</a> Eastern Division, and finished 14th in their first season and third in the season after that (<a href="1929%E2%80%9330%20Southern%20Football%20League">1929–30</a>). This was enough for them to gain election to the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20South">Football League Third Division South</a> in the summer of 1930, in place of <a href="Merthyr%20Town%20F.C.">Merthyr Town</a>. Their request to join the league was considered alongside applications from <a href="Aldershot%20F.C.">Aldershot</a>, <a href="Llanelli%20Town%20A.F.C.">Llanelli</a> and <a href="Argonauts%20F.C.">Argonauts</a>. The success of their application required them to suddenly upgrade the quality of the team. To achieve this objective, the newly promoted club placed an advert for "First Class Players Wanted. All Positions" in the June edition of the <a href="Athletic%20News">Athletic News</a>. Thames continued to field a reserve side in the Southern League for a single further season, before withdrawing entirely in 1931.
Thames' spell in the Football League was a short and unhappy one. The club struggled to attract spectators. It established a supporters group, which at one point had over 1,000 members. However, this effort did not translate into a reliable supporter base that would regularly attend matches. Despite the stadium's capacity of 120,000 (making it the largest ground in England to regularly host League football), the club holds the record for the lowest known attendance for a Saturday Football League match; just 469 fans paid to watch Thames play <a href="Luton%20Town%20F.C.">Luton Town</a> on 6 December 1930.
Unable to compete with established teams nearby, such as <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a>, <a href="Leyton%20Orient%20F.C.">Clapton Orient</a>, <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a> and <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a>, Thames struggled. By December 1931, the club was under severe financial pressure. To keep the club afloat, the players agreed to take a pay cut. They finished 20th out of 22 clubs in <a href="1930%E2%80%9331%20in%20English%20football">1930–31</a>, and 22nd (i.e., bottom) the following season (<a href="1931%E2%80%9332%20in%20English%20football">1931–32</a>). This prompted the club directors' decision not to seek re-election to the League for the following season and wind up the club, despite an approach from Clapton Orient to merge the two clubs. They were replaced by <a href="Aldershot%20F.C.">Aldershot</a>.
Thames AFC should not be confused with Thames Ironworks FC, a club that had predated them by over 30 years, and would go on to be renamed <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a>.
Players.
Notable players for Thames included former <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> international <a href="Jimmy%20Dimmock">Jimmy Dimmock</a>, former <a href="Wales%20national%20football%20team">Welsh</a> internationals <a href="Len%20Davies">Len Davies</a> and <a href="Moses%20Russell">Moses Russell</a> and ex-<a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> striker <a href="Henry%20White%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201895%29">Henry White</a>. <a href="Eddie%20Perry%20%28footballer%29">Eddie Perry</a> went on to be a <a href="Wales%20national%20football%20team">Welsh</a> international.
Colours.
Thames' home colours were red and blue quartered shirts with white shorts and black socks with red and blue trim.
Records and statistics.
Thames' record for their two seasons in the Football League was played 84, won 20, drew 17, lost 47, scored 107 and conceded 202. The club's record league win was 6–3, against <a href="Mansfield%20Town%20F.C.">Mansfield Town</a> on 2 April 1932, while their record league loss was 8–0, against <a href="Luton%20Town%20F.C.">Luton Town</a> on 11 April 1931 and <a href="Fulham%20F.C.">Fulham</a> on 28 March 1932. The furthest they ever reached in the FA Cup was the First Round proper, in <a href="1929%E2%80%9330%20FA%20Cup">1929–30</a>, <a href="1930%E2%80%9331%20FA%20Cup">1930–31</a> and <a href="1931%E2%80%9332%20FA%20Cup">1931–32</a>.
In total, 103,698 fans watched all of Thames' games, at an average of 2,469 per game, which ranks them as 122 out of all the 130 Football League teams in terms of attendance. The club's record highest attendance was approximately 8,000, against <a href="Exeter%20City%20F.C.">Exeter City</a> in August 1931.
